comment_text: This ended in failure for me, with everything melting into a puddle. Want to know why? Fructose melts at at 103 C (217.4 F) and Gluctose melts at at 146 C (294.8 F). So you saying to bake this at 150 C (~300 F) is way overshooting this.

1. equilibrium of anomeric and ring forms
2. Sucrose inversion
3.condensation reaction
4. Intramolecular bonding
5. Isomerization of aldoses to ketoses
6. Dehydration reactions
7. fragmentation reaction
8. Unsaturated polymer formation

Great science content! Aaaaaand...I don't think you need to steer sugar so violently when making caramel. The stuff that sticks to the side of the pan will burn faster (because they have little mass) and gives the caramel sauce a burn taste/aroma if it ever gets back in the mix. Just steer gently occasionally to be sure that the bottom is not overheating and burning (which would also be bad).

Alternately you can dissolve the sugar in a bit of water because then you don't have to stress about the bottom burning, but it will take longer because now you need to remove all the water that you added...

Ahhhh! To make super smooth caramel, you typically add things like corn syrup, tartaric acid and water. Those are to help break the sucrose bonds more and to have more fructose molecules than glucose ones. Idk the science behind it, but i think because of the different levels in those sugars, less crystallization occurs.

That and you typically don stir the pot, put anything into the pot (especially a cold metal thermometer) to avoid nucleation sites.

When you make caramel the classic way, don't be afraid to let the caramel get a little amber in color! Don't pull it too soon or you'll lose alot of flavor. Also make sure the butter you add is browned butter. Trust me ;)

Chemist here:

What you're describing are various solid state reactions. When you use high heat, the decomposition into fructose and glucose provides a liquid medium that can be considered a "flux" which helps dissolve the remaining sucrose and accelerate the reaction. Reasonable people can disagree on whether this counts as a "solid state" synthesis or not, but is typically lumped in that category because it's sued to make solid state materials.

Traditional "ceramic method" solid state synthesis keeps everything in the solid phase and typically requires much longer times (since solid state diffusion is highly inefficient). It's highly likely that using this method
A) is at low conversion, you should keep it in the oven longer
B) actually makes a different caramel since the lack of efficient mixing will change the distribution of products from caramelization (whether you can taste the difference? idk!)

Also: the papers on the melting point of sucrose are a bit nonsensical. No self respecting chemist will report a melting point if it decomposes before melting. That's bad science. Theorists can quibble about the theoretical melting point (and I think that ahs academic merit for building models), but it's a bit irrelevant to the experimentalist.

Long story short he overcooked the sugar to the point that when he tried to remove it from the non stick pan the PTFE coating was removed from the pan and was stuck with the caramelized sugar, rendering it useless...

Ok so the point is that sugar falls apart and changes form before it actually melts, and so there isn't really a melting point you can define for regular sugar. Only the components it falls apart into.

So is it possible, in principle, to establish surrounding conditions that prevent this and allow us to properly find a melting point for sugar "in full"?
Like, maybe under high pressure the bonds will break more slowly? Or under low pressure the melting point is so much lower, that the bonds don't break yet?
Or maybe there's a catalyst allowing us to do it at least statistically? Something that eases the reaction of bond formation, thereby allowing for longer chains even at higher temperatures? While somehow not really affecting the theoretical melting point much? And not overshooting to turn into like flour or something?
